title: Case Study 6: Liz Latency
chief_complaint: I'm having trouble hearing in my left ear after getting hit by a ball during a softball game.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset following blunt trauma (softball accident).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Denies ear pain, drainage, tinnitus, or aural fullness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is consulting a lawyer regarding the accident.

history.present_illness: Patient reports difficulty hearing in the left ear after being hit by a softball. She is currently consulting with a lawyer.
history.otologic_history: Denies pain, drainage, tinnitus, or fullness.
history.noise_exposure_history: Reports frequent attendance at bars/clubs with very loud music over the past 2 years.
history.medical_psych_history: None reported other than the recent trauma.
history.patient_goals: Evaluation for legal consultation and hearing assessment.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Type A tympanogram. Left ear: Type Ad tympanogram with high static admittance (5.9 mmhos).

tests.name: Wideband Acoustic Immittance (Reflectance)
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal reflectance. Left ear: Dip/notch below normal range at 300-800 Hz.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear presents with normal hearing sensitivity. Left ear presents with a moderate hearing loss based on PTA.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores bilaterally. Left ear testing required masking.

tests.name: Stenger Test
tests.key_findings: Stenger test was negative, suggesting the unilateral hearing loss is organic rather than functional/non-organic.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflex Thresholds
tests.key_findings: Right Ipsi present at 90 dB HL. Left Ipsi and Contralateral reflexes are absent (NR).

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals normal hearing sensitivity in the right ear and a moderate conductive hearing loss in the left ear (PTA 55 dB HL). Word recognition is excellent in the left ear when presented at suprathreshold levels (94% at 85 dB HL). Middle ear function is abnormal in the left ear, evidenced by a Type Ad tympanogram (Ytm 5.9 mmhos) and a reflectance dip at 300-800 Hz. The negative Stenger test supports the validity of the left-sided hearing loss, consistent with the reported trauma.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a moderate hearing loss in your left ear, likely related to the recent injury.
The tests for your middle ear system show abnormalities consistent with a conductive loss.
We performed a specialized test called the Stenger test, which confirms that your hearing loss is genuine.
Given your history of loud music exposure, it is critical to protect your hearing in both ears, but especially your 'good' right ear, from further noise damage.
We should discuss options for hearing management, such as amplification, and ensure you have medical clearance from an ENT physician regarding the trauma.
notes_for_actor: You are a 22-year-old involved in a potential lawsuit regarding a softball injury.
You may appear slightly guarded or anxious about the results due to the legal implications.
However, you are not faking the hearing loss; the loss is real (organic), so you should consistently demonstrate difficulty hearing on the left side during the interaction.
